meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Thu 2026-01-29 in Rockford, MI: very cold but quiet weather—no snow/ice precipitation expected (0.0" snowfall, 0.00" liquid), light winds (max ~8 mph), and generally adequate visibility. In Michigan, this setup typically does NOT produce a snow day because plows can easily keep up (there’s nothing to plow) and winds are too light for blowing/drifting. The main impact is cold: wind chills near/below 0°F at times (especially late evening), which can affect bus stops and outdoor exposure, but cold alone rarely closes schools unless accompanied by extreme wind chills. Net: low snow-day likelihood for Thursday.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Cold, dry post-front day: overcast/partly cloudy with no new precipitation and light winds (roughly 2–8 mph). This is the classic “recovery/cleanup day” after a prior lake-effect/clipper event—schools usually remain open unless roads were not cleared well the prior evening or there is a hidden-ice problem.

Cold morning commute with wind chills in the single digits above 0°F (and occasionally near/just below 0°F), but without extreme wind chill (not in the -15°F wind chill range). In Michigan, this level of cold alone rarely triggers closure; it more often results in “bundle up” messaging or limited outdoor recess changes.

Lingering slick-spot risk day: temperatures stay below freezing all day after prior-day light snow/freezing rain. Even with no new precip, untreated surfaces (parking lots, sidewalks, some rural bridges) can stay icy. Closures are uncommon, but delays can happen if there was measurable ice or if overnight refreeze follows daytime melting (not strongly indicated here due to subfreezing temps).

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in West Michigan commonly supports sustained subfreezing temperatures and occasional lake-effect bursts. A day with a high near 16°F and low near -6°F is wintry but not automatically disruptive—especially if snowfall is near zero and winds are modest.
unusual_factors: No forecast snow/rain on the target day (0" new accumulation), which strongly lowers closure odds compared with typical closure setups.

Very cold overnight low (around -6°F) and morning wind chills generally in the single digits above 0°F—noticeably cold, but not in the more closure-prone extreme wind chill threshold (often cited around -15°F wind chill).
Preceding day includes light freezing rain / light snow signals in the broader forecast data, which raises the *black ice* / slick-spot concern despite the dry target-day forecast.

local_microclimates: West Michigan lake-effect variability: narrow snow bands can create big differences over a few miles. Even if Rockford is quiet, nearby corridors can be slick if a band clipped them earlier (more relevant to Wednesday than Thursday given Thursday’s 0" forecast).
River valleys/low spots and shaded roads can hold ice longer during prolonged subfreezing stretches (parking lots, secondary roads, and bridge decks are typical problem areas).
infrastructure_considerations: Rockford/Greater Grand Rapids area generally has strong plowing/salting capacity; with no new snow Thursday, roads typically improve rather than degrade through the morning.
If any freezing rain residue or compacted snow remains from Wednesday, below-freezing temps prevent melt-off, so spot treatments matter for school lots/bus loops.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford is not high-elevation, so there’s no major terrain-driven snow amplification; localized effects are more about lake-effect bands and surface type (bridges/shaded areas) than elevation.

history.confidence_assessment: For Thursday 2026-01-29, the forecast is cold but quiet: high ~16°F, low ~-6°F, light winds, and 0" new snow. In Michigan, this pattern historically corresponds to schools staying open the vast majority of the time. The main operational risk is leftover slickness/black ice from Wednesday’s light wintry mix/lake-effect impacts, especially on untreated surfaces and rural/secondary roads. Absent a surprise lake-effect band or verified widespread ice, a full snow day looks unlikely; at most, a limited delay would be tied to morning road condition reports rather than the Thursday precipitation forecast.

safety_recommendations: Overall snow-day need is LOW for Thursday 2026-01-29: no new snow/precip is forecast (0.0"), winds are light (generally <10 mph), and visibility is generally good—so active weather impacts are minimal.

Primary risk is *cold + refreeze* from prior-day freezing rain/light snow (Wednesday 2026-01-28) leading to isolated slick spots on untreated surfaces (bridges, shaded curves, neighborhood streets, driveways, parking lots, and sidewalks).

Overnight and early-morning temps remain well below freezing (around 12–13°F with wind chills near 0–5°F), so any residual moisture will stay frozen; expect black-ice potential where melt/freeze cycles or treatment gaps exist.

Bus and driver operations: run normal routes but use “winter cautions” on secondary/subdivision roads; increase following distance and reduce speed on approaches to stops/turns. Spot-check known trouble areas (hills, stop-controlled intersections, bridge decks).

Walking safety: ensure sidewalks/entries are salted before student arrival; emphasize traction on steps/ramps and at drop-off/pick-up zones. Cold exposure is a secondary concern—encourage full winter gear for waits at bus stops.
Decision support: if local road patrols report widespread refreeze/black ice at daybreak, consider a DELAY rather than a full closure; otherwise normal opening is supported by this forecast.

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreements across experts: All agree Thu is cold but largely quiet with no meaningful new snow; closure, if any, would be driven by residual/black ice rather than active snowfall. Power-grid risk is negligible.
2) Disagreements: News/infrastructure referenced “anticipated icy roads,” but meteorology indicates no Thu precip. Follow-ups clarify the ice concern is predominantly refreeze/leftover slick spots, not new freezing drizzle. Visibility “0-mile” entries are treated as likely data artifacts absent corroboration.
3) Plow timing math: With no accumulating snow Thu, this is not a plow-capacity event. There are ~21 hours from Wed lingering impacts to Thu 6:30 AM; main routes are expected serviceable by bus time, but patchy slick spots can persist on low-priority streets/bridges.
4) Ice present? Potential is moderate but expected to be patchy (bridges, shaded curves, parking lots, subdivisions), not widespread on primaries.
5) Neighboring districts: Latest checks did not find confirmed Thu 1/29 closures/delays among nearby districts (GRPS/Kentwood/Northview/Sparta/Cedar Springs), and no strong community buzz surfaced.
6) Power outages: Extremely low; no school-facility outage signal.
7) Wind chill verification: NWS digital/hourly table confirms ~+1°F wind chill at 6–8 AM Thu—nowhere near ≤ -20°F.
8) What would make this wrong: If early Thu road checks reveal widespread glaze/hard-pack on secondary/residential bus routes (numerous slide-offs, consistent braking problems), Rockford could opt for a 2-hour delay or, less likely, a closure.

Weighting (per directive): Meteorology strongly suppresses closure odds (dry, light wind). Safety/infrastructure keep non-zero risk due to refreeze and patchy black ice. News intel found no neighboring-district closure cascade. Power and web verification remove two major “automatic” drivers (outages, extreme wind chill). Net: low probability of a full snow day; higher probability of a delay than closure.

alternative_scenarios.impact: Travel becomes broadly unsafe for buses/teen drivers; closure justified

for_schools: Plan to OPEN as normal, but be ready to pivot to a 2-hour delay based on 5:30–6:15 AM road checks and transportation supervisor reports
Prioritize pre-6:30 AM salting/sanding of: bus loops, drop-off lanes, main entrances, steps/ramps, and staff parking areas
Send a parent/staff message emphasizing black-ice risk on neighborhood streets/driveways and cold-weather gear for bus stops
for_residents: Assume black ice on bridges/ramps/shaded roads; slow down early Thu and increase following distance
Wear traction-friendly footwear; use handrails and treat home driveways/walks
Allow extra time for commute even if roads look “mostly clear”
for_authorities: Continue bridge/overpass pretreatment and early-morning spot treatment on known trouble corridors
If possible, publish a brief early-AM roadway status update (even if ‘mostly clear but patchy’) to reduce uncertainty
Monitor incident/slide-off clusters 5–8 AM to identify whether conditions are patchy vs widespread

positions.rationale: Meteorologically, Thursday (2026-01-29) in Rockford, MI looks cold but quiet: overcast/partly cloudy, no snowfall/ice forecast, and light winds. That combination rarely produces a full closure because there’s nothing new accumulating, and winds aren’t high enough to create visibility or drifting problems. The only credible pathway to a snow day is if Wednesday’s wintry mix/lake-effect left widespread untreated ice/hardpack that remains slick into Thursday morning (temps stay below freezing), but that’s more consistent with a *delay* than a full closure. Net: low snow-day probability, non-zero due to residual ice risk and some visibility/icing uncertainty in cross-source verification.
keyFactors: No new precip expected Thu 2026-01-29 (0 mm / 0 cm snow; snow chance 0%) — removes the primary closure trigger.
Winds are light (generally 2–8 mph; max ~8.3 mph). That strongly limits blowing/drifting and keeps wind-chill impacts from reaching the more closure-prone extremes.

Temperatures are very cold (high ~16°F; low ~-6°F), but forecast wind chills during school-commute hours are mostly in the +2°F to +5°F range, not the -15°F or colder range that more commonly drives closures on “cold-only” days.
Synoptic setup looks like a cold, stable post-event day (high pressure-ish: pressures ~1022–1026 mb, no precip signal) — usually a ‘cleanup’ day, not a ‘worsening’ day.

Residual hazard risk is mainly *leftover* (black ice / hard-pack) from Wed 2026-01-28 light freezing rain/snow, but with no new precip overnight Thu, widespread deterioration is less likely than localized slick spots.

positions.rationale: For Thursday, January 29, 2026, the forecast is very cold but quiet: 0" additional snow, no rain/ice, and light winds. In the historical record of Michigan school operations, that combination rarely produces a full snow day. The realistic disruption pathway is not Thursday’s weather itself but lingering impacts from Wednesday’s wintry mix/lake-effect (black ice, hard-pack on neighborhood roads, and icy school lots/bus loops). That tail risk supports a small-but-nontrivial closure probability, though it more strongly supports a delay scenario rather than cancellation. Net: low odds of a snow day, modest uncertainty driven by how bad Wednesday’s road/ice outcomes actually are locally by daybreak Thursday.
keyFactors: Historical pattern match: Thu 2026-01-29 looks like a classic post-event “cold, dry cleanup day” (no new precip, light winds). Historically these are overwhelmingly *open* days in West Michigan unless the previous 12–18 hours produced widespread ice/snow that can’t be treated in time.

Cold alone usually isn’t enough: temps around 12–16°F with wind chills mostly a few degrees above 0°F (with colder wind chills mainly late evening) are typically not at the threshold that drives full closures; districts more often adjust outdoor time rather than cancel school.

Residual-ice tail risk from Wed 2026-01-28: prior-day light freezing rain/light snow + subfreezing temps can preserve slick spots on bridges/secondary roads/parking lots. That can produce a *delay* if morning road checks come back poor, but full closures are still uncommon without ongoing precip or significant accumulation.
Local capability: Rockford/Grand Rapids-area road agencies typically handle a no-new-precip day well; risk concentrates on untreated surfaces and rural segments rather than systemwide failure.

positions.rationale: From a safety/operations standpoint, Thursday looks like a *post-event recovery day*: very cold, dry, and light wind. That combination usually keeps main roads stable and improves travel compared with the prior day. The main credible pathway to a snow day is if residual ice/hard-pack from Wed 2026-01-28 remains widespread on secondary and residential roads at daybreak (or if there’s an unexpected localized lake-effect band), creating unacceptable bus-route risk. Given the forecast of zero additional precip and limited wind, I’m weighting the outcome toward ‘open’ with winter cautions, with a meaningful but not dominant chance of a 2-hour delay if early road checks find broad slick spots. Net effect: low-to-moderate closure probability, higher for delay than closure.
keyFactors: No new precip expected Thu 2026-01-29 (0.0" snow / 0.00" liquid) and light winds (max ~8 mph) → low likelihood of widespread hazardous travel.

Primary safety driver is *leftover slickness* from Wed 2026-01-28 wintry mix/lake-effect impacts + sustained subfreezing temps → patchy black ice on bridges, shaded roads, parking lots, sidewalks, and some secondary/residential roads.

Morning commute window (about 06:00–09:00) aligns with coldest/least-treated surfaces; even if arterials are fine, school buses and student drivers are exposed to neighborhood roads and stop-controlled intersections.

Cold exposure is notable (wind chills near/just below 0°F at times; later evening colder), but not typically at the level that alone triggers closures in this region—more likely to affect outdoor arrival/recess practices than operations.

The strongest “soft signal” for disruption is the local road-commission preparedness messaging about potential icing; that pattern more often produces a delay than a full closure when actual precip is near-zero.

positions.rationale: From a news/operations perspective, I weight *official district communications and public-works posture* heavily. The FOX 17/Kent County Road Commission “prepping for ice” item is the strongest forward-looking closure/delay signal for Thu 2026-01-29, but it conflicts with the actual provided Thu forecast (no precip) and the absence (so far) of Rockford Public Schools messaging for Thursday. That combination points to: schools likely open, with a non-trivial chance of a **delay** if early-morning road checks find widespread black ice on secondary roads/bridges from Wednesday’s wintry mix. Netting those factors, I land in the low-teens for a full snow day probability.
keyFactors: **No new precip forecast for Thu 2026-01-29** (0" snow / 0" liquid): removes the biggest driver of full closures.

**Very cold but not extreme wind-chill territory for most of the school commute** (generally single digits above 0°F feels-like in the morning per provided hourly data). Cold alone in West Michigan more often changes recess/bus-stop guidance than closes schools.

**‘Leftover slick spots’ is the main plausible disruption mechanism**: Wednesday (2026-01-28) includes light freezing rain / light snow signals in the feed, and temps stay below freezing all day Thursday—so any untreated moisture/compacted snow won’t melt away.

**Operational/news signals are mixed**: KCRC preparation messaging (as relayed by FOX 17) is a *yellow flag* for the Thursday morning commute, but (a) it’s not the same as an active warning for Kent County on Thursday, and (b) Rockford Public Schools had no posted Thu 1/29 closure/delay at time checked.
**No outage / infrastructure crisis signal**: low power-outage counts and light winds reduce the chance of “non-weather” closures (power, heat, signal outages).

debates.topic: The meteorology write-up leans heavily on ‘no precip Thursday’ (correct) but may underweight the *operational* impact of Wednesday’s freezing rain/light snow + persistent subfreezing temps—conditions where untreated ice can remain hazardous into the next morning even without new weather. I agree it’s still low-likelihood for a full closure, but the tail risk should not be near-zero.
debates.challenge: The meteorology write-up leans heavily on ‘no precip Thursday’ (correct) but may underweight the *operational* impact of Wednesday’s freezing rain/light snow + persistent subfreezing temps—conditions where untreated ice can remain hazardous into the next morning even without new weather. I agree it’s still low-likelihood for a full closure, but the tail risk should not be near-zero.

debates.topic: The Kent County Road Commission ‘anticipated icy roads’ signal is important, but it can be easy to over-convert preparedness messaging into closure probability. KCRC pre-treating bridges at 4 a.m. can just as easily indicate mitigation is underway—supporting delays at most, not necessarily closures—especially with no new precip in the forecast feed.
debates.challenge: The Kent County Road Commission ‘anticipated icy roads’ signal is important, but it can be easy to over-convert preparedness messaging into closure probability. KCRC pre-treating bridges at 4 a.m. can just as easily indicate mitigation is underway—supporting delays at most, not necessarily closures—especially with no new precip in the forecast feed.

debates.topic: The safety analysis flags ‘moderate’ morning commute impact; I’d caution against mapping that directly to snow-day likelihood. Historically, ‘moderate’ hazard in West Michigan often yields normal opening or a delay, with closures reserved for widespread untreated ice or active heavy snow at commute time.
debates.challenge: The safety analysis flags ‘moderate’ morning commute impact; I’d caution against mapping that directly to snow-day likelihood. Historically, ‘moderate’ hazard in West Michigan often yields normal opening or a delay, with closures reserved for widespread untreated ice or active heavy snow at commute time.

debates.topic: Hourly visibility fields include multiple 0-mile entries despite no precip/fog signal; if that’s a data artifact, fine—but if it reflects real dense fog/ice-crystal haze risk, it could materially increase crash risk in the 06:00–09:00 window. Recommend clarifying whether those 0-vis hours are trustworthy.
debates.challenge: Hourly visibility fields include multiple 0-mile entries despite no precip/fog signal; if that’s a data artifact, fine—but if it reflects real dense fog/ice-crystal haze risk, it could materially increase crash risk in the 06:00–09:00 window. debates.topic: Road-commission ‘prepping for anticipated icy roads’ is a strong headline, but we should separate *preparedness* from *expected severity* given the Thu precip forecast is 0.0". If that coverage is about a thin-film icing/refreeze scenario, it supports delay probability; if it’s about an event that’s now fizzled, it may be overweighted.

debates.topic: Historical snow-day rates cited (4–9%) may understate risk when the preceding day includes freezing rain signals—ice is less forgiving than snow and can trigger more conservative decisions even with low accumulations. Consider conditioning the base rate on ‘prior-day glaze/freezing rain’ cases.
debates.challenge: Historical snow-day rates cited (4–9%) may understate risk when the preceding day includes freezing rain signals—ice is less forgiving than snow and can trigger more conservative decisions even with low accumulations. Consider conditioning the base rate on ‘prior-day glaze/freezing rain’ cases.

debates.topic: You treat Thursday as ‘quiet’ (agree), but the dataset shows many early-hour visibility entries as 0 miles/0 km. That could be a data artifact, but if it reflects real fog/ice-crystal haze, it could amplify morning travel risk even without precip. I’d like a sanity check on whether those 0-visibility hours are trustworthy.

debates.topic: Historical closure rates cited (4–9%) feel plausible, but may underweight the **sequence effect** (recent closures + prolonged subfreezing temps preserving ice). If neighboring districts already closed earlier in the week (e.g., Tue 1/27), superintendent risk tolerance sometimes shifts. Consider adding a small ‘recent-disruption momentum’ adjustment.

debates.topic: Your ‘worst conditions 06:00–09:00’ window aligns with commute risk, but I’d push for distinguishing **delay vs closure** explicitly in the scoring. A moderate black-ice risk in West Michigan often yields a 2-hour delay rather than a full closure, especially with no new precip.

debates.topic: My own news inputs include a FOX 17 “anticipated icy roads / crews starting early Thursday” framing that may be based on an earlier model run. Without a fresh NWS/KCRC update for Wed night/Thu morning, that headline could overweight icing risk relative to the latest forecast showing 0 precip. I’d downgrade that factor unless reconfirmed later today.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: Meteorologically, Thursday (2026-01-29) in Rockford, MI looks cold but quiet: overcast/partly cloudy, no snowfall/ice forecast, and light winds. That combination rarely produces a full closure because there’s nothing new accumulating, and winds aren’t high enough to create visibility or drifting problems. The only credible pathway to a snow day is if Wednesday’s wintry mix/lake-effect left widespread untreated ice/hardpack that remains slick into Thursday morning (temps stay below freezing), but that’s more consistent with a *delay* than a full closure. Net: low snow-day probability, non-zero due to residual ice risk and some visibility/icing uncertainty in cross-source verification.

For Thursday, January 29, 2026, the forecast is very cold but quiet: 0" additional snow, no rain/ice, and light winds. In the historical record of Michigan school operations, that combination rarely produces a full snow day. The realistic disruption pathway is not Thursday’s weather itself but lingering impacts from Wednesday’s wintry mix/lake-effect (black ice, hard-pack on neighborhood roads, and icy school lots/bus loops). That tail risk supports a small-but-nontrivial closure probability, though it more strongly supports a delay scenario rather than cancellation. Net: low odds of a snow day, modest uncertainty driven by how bad Wednesday’s road/ice outcomes actually are locally by daybreak Thursday.

From a safety/operations standpoint, Thursday looks like a *post-event recovery day*: very cold, dry, and light wind. That combination usually keeps main roads stable and improves travel compared with the prior day. The main credible pathway to a snow day is if residual ice/hard-pack from Wed 2026-01-28 remains widespread on secondary and residential roads at daybreak (or if there’s an unexpected localized lake-effect band), creating unacceptable bus-route risk. Given the forecast of zero additional precip and limited wind, I’m weighting the outcome toward ‘open’ with winter cautions, with a meaningful but not dominant chance of a 2-hour delay if early road checks find broad slick spots. Net effect: low-to-moderate closure probability, higher for delay than closure.

From a news/operations perspective, I weight *official district communications and public-works posture* heavily. The FOX 17/Kent County Road Commission “prepping for ice” item is the strongest forward-looking closure/delay signal for Thu 2026-01-29, but it conflicts with the actual provided Thu forecast (no precip) and the absence (so far) of Rockford Public Schools messaging for Thursday. That combination points to: schools likely open, with a non-trivial chance of a **delay** if early-morning road checks find widespread black ice on secondary roads/bridges from Wednesday’s wintry mix. Netting those factors, I land in the low-teens for a full snow day probability.

keyDisagreements.topic: The FOX 17/Kent County Road Commission ‘anticipated icy roads’ story is a useful signal, but it may reflect *precautionary operations* rather than confirming precip/icing is actually expected in Rockford overnight into Thu. If the meteorological forecast truly has 0 precip, I’d want clarity on whether that ‘icing’ refers to refreeze/black ice from prior moisture vs. new freezing drizzle.
positions: The FOX 17/Kent County Road Commission ‘anticipated icy roads’ story is a useful signal, but it may reflect *precautionary operations* rather than confirming precip/icing is actually expected in Rockford overnight into Thu. If the meteorological forecast truly has 0 precip, I’d want clarity on whether that ‘icing’ refers to refreeze/black ice from prior moisture vs. new freezing drizzle.

keyDisagreements.topic: The safety window ‘worst conditions 06:00–09:00’ is plausible for refreeze risk, but it reads more like an operational assumption than something directly supported by Thu hourly precip (which is 0). I’d encourage tying that window to specific surface-temp/dewpoint spread or known residual moisture timing, otherwise it may overweight the hazard.
positions: The safety window ‘worst conditions 06:00–09:00’ is plausible for refreeze risk, but it reads more like an operational assumption than something directly supported by Thu hourly precip (which is 0). I’d encourage tying that window to specific surface-temp/dewpoint spread or known residual moisture timing, otherwise it may overweight the hazard.

keyDisagreements.topic: Hourly visibility fields show several 0-mile/0-km entries despite no precip/fog coded. That is likely a data-quality artifact (common in some feeds) and should not be treated as true dense fog unless corroborated. If it *is* real, it would materially raise delay risk even without snow.
positions: Hourly visibility fields show several 0-mile/0-km entries despite no precip/fog coded. That is likely a data-quality artifact (common in some feeds) and should not be treated as true dense fog unless corroborated. If it *is* real, it would materially raise delay risk even without snow.

keyDisagreements.topic: Historical analog rates are reasonable, but the ‘lingering slick-spot’ scenario depends heavily on what actually fell Wed (amount/type and treatment). Without observed road-condition confirmation, that branch should stay low-weight for predicting full closure (though it matters for delay odds).

collaboration.collaborationSummary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 9.0% spread. Average probability: 12%.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 28 at 3:45AM EST until January 28 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations up to one inch.

* WHERE...Allegan, Ottawa, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...Until 10 AM EST this morning.

* IMPACTS...Roads will likely be slick and hazardous. Visibility and
road conditions may change rapidly over short distances in lake
effect snow. The hazardous conditions will impact the Wednesday
morning commute.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of ongoing lake effect snow,
which we expect to increase in intensity during the morning
commute, as well as cold temperatures will result in slick travel
conditions.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 27 at 4:05PM EST until January 28 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.


* WHERE...A portion of west central Michigan, including the
following county, Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Ice jams are notoriously unpredictable. Low-lying areas
along the Muskegon River that are prone to flooding may see
rapidly changing water levels as ice shifts and adjusts.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 318 PM EST, An ice jam was reported by local authorities
on the Muskegon river in southern Newaygo County. The river
gauge at Newaygo shows water levels remaining at minor flood
stage as of Tuesday afternoon.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. While
flooding associated with freeze up ice jams is typically
minor, conditions can change rapidly and unpredictably.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Newaygo.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.
